Commandline

What‚Äôs a Command Line Interface (CLI)

It‚Äôs a way of interacting with your computer (or‚Ä¶ errr‚Ä¶ another computer?)

  • you give it instructions by typing a command
  • a command is some sequence of characters
  • after you press <ENTER>, the computer does stuff!
  • you usually get some feedback or output

Command Line Topics

  • command line basics
    • getting around the file system
    • finding and manipulating files
  • other command line tools

Motivation

This is hard! Let‚Äôs go shopping! Why are we learning this? ‚Üí

  • uploading files / working on the server
  • many tools require use of the command line
  • automation
  • experience different platforms / tools
  • lookin‚Äô 1337

Terminal

  • On MacOS, the command line interface using an application called Terminal.
  • Open it. It‚Äôs probably under Applications ‚Üí Utilities. ‚Üí
  • On windows‚Ä¶ ummmm. cmd.exe (or use cmder, cygwin, etc. ‚Ä¶ or use putty to login to a machine with a different OS)

Terminal vs GUI

This is basically an alternative interface to your computer

  • you can do a lot of things in terminal that you can do by clicking through folders, windows, and applications with your trackpad/mouse
  • it‚Äôs primarily text based input and output

Demo: A Quick Tour

In your OS‚Ä¶ how do you? ‚Üí

  • create, copy, edit, and list files
    • (finder, TextEditor, Windows Explorer, Notepad)
  • see processes, stop processes
    • (Activity Monitor / Task Manager)
  • find files
    • (finder, spotlight, cortana ü§¶‚Äç)

Welllllll‚Ä¶ you can do all of that through the terminal!

Entering Commands

Commands

Commands are verbs; they tell the computer to do something.

Entering a Command

Once you have Terminal open, you should see a string of characters that ends with a dollar sign. This is called the command prompt. A prompt looks something like this.

 walsh-9:~ joe$

Whenever you see a line in these slides prefixed with a $, that means that we‚Äôre typing something in at the prompt.

Executing a Command

In terminal, type in the name of the command, and press <ENTER>. Let‚Äôs trying using ls, a command to list files and directories ‚Üí

  • open Terminal (Applications ‚Üí Utilities ‚Üí Terminal
  • type ls
  • press <ENTER>

$ ls

Where Are You?

Note that when you‚Äôre at the prompt, you‚Äôre always running commands in the context of some location on your computer.

  • This location corresponds to an actual directory.
  • You can change where you are using various commands. We‚Äôll see that later.

Let‚Äôs Repeat That: At the prompt, you‚Äôre running commands in the context of some location (think folder/directory) on your computer

What Was That Again?

  • when you‚Äôre at the prompt
  • and you type in a command
  • you‚Äôre doing so while you‚Äôre in a particular folder/directory
  • you‚Äôre always located somewhere on your file system

Arguments

Arguments are the thing or things that a command acts on; they‚Äôre like nouns (or more formally, direct objects).

Commands and Arguments

Some commands can optionally have arguments:

  • they go after the command name
  • a command may potentially be able to take 0 or more arguments

Try this (list files in Desktop):


$ ls Desktop

Flags

Flags are like adverbs. They specify how a command is run.

(sometimes they‚Äôre also called options)

Commands and Flags

Commands can optionally have flags.

  • they go after the command name, but usually before arguments
  • they are specified with either - or ‚Äì
  • commands may have 0 or more flags.

Try this (list all, including hidden, files in Desktop):‚Üí


$ ls -a Desktop

<TAB> Completion

You can use the <TAB> key to complete commands or file names. Try typing the following:‚Üí

  • ls Desk<TAB>
  • What happens? ‚Üí

The argument, Desktop, is automatically completed for you! Go ahead and run the command by pressing <ENTER> ‚Üí

<TAB><TAB>

What if there are multiple matches? Type the letter l and then <TAB>. What happens? ‚Üí

Nothing. Now try hitting <TAB> one more time. What happens? ‚Üí

All of the possible commands that start with the letter l are shown.

Next and Previous Commands

You can use the <UP> or <DOWN> keys to go through previous and next commands. Try pressing <UP> twice, and <DOWN> once. What command is shown?


$ ls Desktop

Errors

Type the letter l and press <ENTER>.


$ l

What happens? ‚Üí


-bash: l: command not found

More Errors

Type ls foo and press <ENTER>.


$ ls foo

What happens? ‚Üí


ls: foo: No such file or directory

Navigating the File System

In Three Parts
  • OSX‚Äôs directory structure
  • A little bit about pathnames
  • How to get around using the commandline

Let‚Äôs Look at the MacOS Directory Structure

First, Some Definitions

What‚Äôs a directory? ‚Üí

  • a directory is a cataloging structure on a file system that references other files (and directories)
  • we can think of it as a thing that contains files (it‚Äôs a little more complex than that, though)
  • they‚Äôre usually used to organize files

More Definitions

What‚Äôs a folder? ‚Üí

  • it‚Äôs essentially the same thing as a directory
  • but it‚Äôs the graphical representation (like the little folder icons in finder)

Even More Definitions

What‚Äôs a pathname? ‚Üí

  • a pathname is the general form of the name of a file or directory; it specifies a unique location in a file system
  • for example, in finder, to locate a file or folder, you follow a particular path - let‚Äôs check this out ‚Üí.
  • what‚Äôs the path to the Desktop starting from the top most folder, the hard drive (probably Macintosh HD on the lab computers)? ‚Üí

Some Structure

Each operating system organizes their files and directories differently. OSX‚Äôs file structure looks like this (it‚Äôs similar to other UNIX based file systems):

  • / - (also called root) the top most folder on a disk (the directory that contains all of the other files and directories)
  • /Applications - where shared applications are kept
  • /Users - all user accounts and their accompanying files are stored here
  • /Volumes - all disks that are attached to your computer including USB drives, hard drives, etc.
  • /System - system specific files, libraries, preferences that are critical to the operating system

More About the User‚Äôs Directory

It‚Äôs worth noting the directories nested under Users. They should seem familiar to you.

  • /Users/username - (also called home when you‚Äôre in your own username‚Äôs directory) contains files specific to that particular user
  • /Users/username/Desktop - represents the user‚Äôs Desktop
  • /Users/username/Downloads - the user‚Äôs downloads folder

And Now‚Ä¶ To Pathnames!

We know a little bit about the file system structure; let's take a closer look at how we locate files

What‚Äôs a Pathname Again?

A pathname is the general form of the name of a file or directory; it specifies a unique location in a file system.

Path Separator

A path separator is a character that‚Äôs used to join together each directory in a pathname that contains nested directories (for example, Desktop was located under Users and username‚Ä¶ there was a character that separated each directory).

What character represents the path separator on MacOS (we just saw this)? ‚Üí

  • it‚Äôs a forward slash, /
  • (sometimes just called slash when referencing directories)
  • it‚Äôs not backslash (that‚Äôs the path separator for Windows!)

Absolute vs Relative Paths

  • absolute paths are paths expressed as starting from root
    • example: /Users/username/Desktop
  • relative paths are paths expressed as relative from the current working directory
    • example (if you‚Äôre starting from /Users/username): Desktop

Some Special Paths

There are shortcuts to represent specific paths:

  • ~ (tilde) is your home directory
  • / (slash) is root directory

The following paths are relative to the directory that you‚Äôre in:

  • . (dot) is the current directory
  • .. (dot dot) is the parent directory
  • ../.. (dot dot slash dot dot) is the parent of the parent directory

Let‚Äôs See Some Pathnames Through Finder

  • Desktop
  • Downloads
  • root (probably Macintosh HD)

Now That We Know About Pathnames, We Can Navigate the File System Using the Commandline! (EXCITED YET!?)

Let's learn some commands

ls

List all of the files (and directories) in the current directory. ‚Üí

Think: list (we just saw this!).


$ ls
Applications	Documents   ....

ls pathname

List all of the files (and directories) in the directory specified by the pathname. ‚Üí


$ ls Desktop
cuny-first.png		fractal mountains

ls -l

The -l flag gives detailed output about each file in the directory ‚Üí

Think: l for long version.


$ ls -l
drwx------   3 joe  staff   102 Nov  1 15:08 Applications
drwx------+  7 joe  staff   238 Jan 28 22:46 Desktop

ls -a

The -a flag lists all files, including hidden ones ‚Üí

Think: a for all.


$ ls -a
.			.config			Dropbox

ls -al

You can combine flags by placing them one after the other. This outputs a detailed list of all files. ‚Üí


$ ls -al
drwxr-xr-x+ 67 joe   staff   2278 Jan 30 02:07 .
drwxr-xr-x   5 root  admin    170 Aug 13  2011 ..
-rw-r--r--@  1 joe   staff  24580 Jan 30 02:19 .DS_Store
-rw-r--r--   1 joe   staff   3459 Mar 21  2011 .RData

ls -t

The -t flag sorts by time. ‚Üí


$ ls -lt
total 0
drwxr-xr-x   2 joe  staff    68 Jan 30 02:07 mtec1002
drwx------@ 19 joe  staff   646 Jan 29 21:21 Dropbox
drwxr-xr-x   9 joe  staff   306 Jan 29 19:31 projects

Combining Flags and Arguments

You can use multiple flags‚Ä¶ and combine them with an argument as well. What do you think this does? ‚Üí


$ ls -alt Desktop

It lists all of the files in Desktop (if you‚Äôre in your home folder), ordered by time, including hidden files and showing extra information.


drwxr-xr-x+ 40 joe  staff    1360 Jan 29 01:12 ..
-rw-r--r--@  1 joe  staff    6148 Jan 25 01:46 .DS_Store
drwx------+  6 joe  staff     204 Jan 24 08:26 .
-rw-r--r--@  1 joe  staff  245447 Jan 23 23:15 cuny-first.png
drwxr-xr-x  16 joe  staff     544 Oct 28 18:46 fractal mountains
-rw-r--r--   1 joe  staff       0 Aug 31 22:41 .localized

pwd

Shows the directory that you‚Äôre currently in. ‚Üí

Think: print working directory.


$ pwd
/Users/joe

hostname

Prints out the name of your computer ‚Üí


$ hostname
walsh-9

mkdir

Creates a directory with the name of the argument supplied. ‚Üí

Think: make directory

One argument is required: the name of the directory to create.


$ mkdir my_animated_gifs

mkdir dir1/dir2/dir3

This attempts to create 3 directories nested within eachother. ‚Üí

Forward slash (/) shows that a directory is within the directory preceding it. dir1/dir2 means dir2 in dir1.

However, nested directories don‚Äôt work as an argument for mkdir. (Unless‚Ä¶)


$ mkdir dir1/dir2
mkdir: dir1: No such file or directory

mkdir -p dir1/dir2

The -p flag allows you to create multiple directories nested within eachother. ‚Üí


mkdir -p dir1/dir2
$ ls
dir1
$ ls dir1
dir2

cd

Changes current directory to the directory specified in the argument. ‚Üí

Think: change directory

One argument is required: the name of the directory to change to.


$ cd Desktop
$ pwd
/Users/joe/Desktop

A Reminder About Special Paths

  • . (dot) is current directory
  • .. (dot dot) is parent directory
  • ../.. (dot dot slash dot dot) is parent of parent directory
  • / (slash) is root directory
  • ~ (tilde) is home directory

Using Special Paths

Let‚Äôs use special paths with cd ‚Üí


$ pwd
/Users/joe
$ cd ../
$ pwd
/Users
$ ls
Shared	joe
$ cd ~
$ pwd
/Users/joe
$ cd /
$ pwd
/

Back to Directory

Pass - (dash) as an argument to cd to go back to the directory you just changed from. ‚Üí


$ pwd
/Users/joe
$ cd /tmp
$ pwd
/tmp
$ cd -
/Users/joe

rmdir

Removes a directory with the name of the argument supplied. ‚Üí

Think: remove directory

One argument is required: the name of the directory to remove.


$ mkdir foo
$ ls
foo
$ rmdir foo
$ ls

pushd/popd

Change to directory, but save current one for later. ‚Üí

  • pushd requires one argument, the directory to change to.
  • you can pushd multiple directories
  • popd takes you back to the last saved directory
  • you can continue to use popd until there are no more saved directories

pushd/popd Continued


$ pwd
/Volumes
$ pushd ~/Desktop/
~/Desktop /Volumes
$ pushd /Applications/
/Applications ~/Desktop /Volumes
$ popd
~/Desktop /Volumes
$ pwd
/Users/joe/Desktop
$ popd
/Volumes

Permissions


chmod 755 foo.html


chmod u+r foo.html
